While Reflective Communication is possible to consider for players operating on their own (in a sense similar to Schön's concept of The Reflective Practitioner), this pattern assumes that the Reflective Communication is between players.
Note: this pattern is modeled upon the concept of Reflective Communication'' first described by Engeström in 1987.

Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hanabi">Hanabi</link></style> may be enticed by the game design to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style>, but this is typically cheating since much of the gameplay challenge in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hanabi">Hanabi</link></style> relates to not knowing what other players know.

For example, <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> can emerge in any game <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> but may be against other players' best interest unless <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> is needed or wanted. While not necessarily implying <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, games where players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> with each other can promote <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> although players engaging in it may use it as a way to manipulate other players rather than cooperating (so they may limit what the openly reflect upon and can led to <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style>).

Looking more broadly, <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> can be encouraged in two main ways: one focusing on making players openly reflect on their own situations and possible actions and the other focusing on making players openly reflect on the other players situations and possible actions. The two ways are not contradictory, and providing one may encourage the other since players become more aware that performing <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> can be beneficial.

Gaming with both <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> and <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> can make players reflect as how their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> would, i.e. reflecting diegetically to the other players. If other players reply diegetically, then the whole <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> can in effect be between <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> as well as between players.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> is a pattern related to communication, how players can do it affects how the pattern emerges during gameplay. This means that <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> can heavily affect if and how <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> takes place while a game is being played.

<style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> can be problematic in some games since it breaks <style="Link"><link="diegetic-communication">Diegetic Communication</link></style> and can result in <style="Link"><link="non-consistent-narration">Non-Consistent Narration</link></style>, both which causes challenges to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style> or issues with perceiving <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>. This can be especially problematic in games with <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, since <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> between players (rather than between <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>) becomes <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> between the people that typically are supposed to both uphold and perceive <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>. In games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/In%20Character%20Conversations">In Character Conversations</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> can break <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> if player perform the <style="CurrentLink">Reflective Communication</style> while enacting their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>.
